top_comment.text:
The mantis shrimp has "among the most advanced eyes in the animal kingdom". 
We have binocular vision, it has sexnocular vision that can detect 12 color 
wavelengths. Oh and it punches its preys with a force of 1500 Newtons.﻿
top_comment.author: Pierre Sermanet

comments.text:
+Dragomir Anguelov I think you don't know that is is 'sexnocular'. +Pierre 
Sermanet humans can detect WAY more than 12 colour wavelengths. Humans have 
3 colour receptive cones whereas the mantis shrimp has 12. We can obviously 
see more than 3 distinct colours, there are just 3 base colours from which 
all colours we see are made: blue, green and red. The amount of light 
absorbed and reflected ultimately determines the colour.  A dog has two 
colour receptive cones (detects green and blue), and butterfly has five 
(detects green, blue, red, ? and ?. It just means they can see 9 different 
BASE colours we can't see (green, blue, red, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ? and ?. 
Which means that it is able to see thousands of times more colours than we 
can. So a rainbow for the mantis shrimp would be like a thermonuclear 
explosion of colours. And a mantis shrimp attempting to explain what any of 
those 9 other colours were to a human would be like a non-colourblind 
person attempting to describe colours most people can see to a blind person 
as each individual colour would be difficult to discern from another.
comments.author: AdmiralSmilez

comments.text: +Drake Sandate .022 lbs of force
comments.author: Killartist3

comments.text:
+Drake Sandate If you just type "define one newton" into Google, you'll get 
the medical definition for the unit of measurement, perfectly phrased.
comments.author: ivaldi13

comments.text: How much is 1 Newton?
comments.author: Drake Sandate

comments.text: +Dragomir Anguelov sexnocular. not six.
comments.author: Mikasa Ackerman

comments.text: Thank you. I didnt pay attention the first time.
comments.author: Engelberg Munoz

comments.text:
+Yann LeCun, with all those photoreceptor types, one might naïvely expect 
fantastic spectral resolution, but recent behavioral tests suggest mantis 
shrimp are significantly worse at color discrimination than humans (25nm vs 
5nm resolution). Of course, the design of the mantis shrimp visual system 
is so alien and our understanding of it is so rudimentary, the tests might 
be asking the wrong question in the wrong way to accurately measure their 
true abilities. 

While all those photoreceptor types do imply a tradeoff loss of spatial 
resolution, in theory some of the spatial resolution can be recovered by 
the way the eye is constructed, such that that 3 different eye regions all 
view the same region of space (trinocular vision in each eye). 

I think we have little clue yet how their target recognition may work!

A couple links for more info:

http://phenomena.nationalgeographic.com/2014/01/23/the-mantis-shrimp-sees-like-a-satellite/

Thoen, How, Choiu & Marshall. 2013. A Different Form of Color Vision in 
Mantis Shrimp. *Science* 
http://dx.doi.org/10.1126/science.1245824
comments.author: Steve Esterly

comments.text:
It has high spectral resolution but low spatial resolution. Makes target 
recognition simpler when you have a small brain.
comments.author: Yann LeCun

during a very tough time. I was having some issues with my PTSD, and all I 
had that night was Hades. I held his little paw between my fingers and fell 
asleep, and when I woke up, he was still there, asleep on my head, with his 
paw in my fingers. He was amazing, and I miss him SO much.

One of my current rats, Mordin will come when he is called. We let him roam 
around the house with supervision... :D

top_comment.text:
Humans can detect 3 wavelengths RGB but various combinations of these 
wavelengths result in a broad spectrum of colors.
Mantis shrimp have 6 rows of light sensitive receptors. 1 through 4 detect 
UV and visible spectrum (meaning the same colors humans see, plus UV.) Rows 
5 and 6 are sensitive to polarized light.
Goodness only knows what this means for their interpretation of the world, 
but the point I'm making is that they don't see 9 times more colors than we 
do. They see the same colors, plus ultraviolet and polarized.﻿
top_comment.author: Justin R

comments.text:
+JLCL01 You're correct, because light is additive, meaning the more light 
you have the brighter the color you get until ultimately a large presence 
of all the colors results in white. Pigments, like paint, are reductive, 
meaning that as you add colors and quantities you end up with black.
comments.author: Justin R

comments.text:
+Derek Hilgefort

What you stated more applies to art or whatnot (I know you can combine 
colors via a glass with colored dye like you can with painting. Thus the 
"or whatnot" bit).

comments.text:
+Derek Hilgefort No, our eyes actually cannot detect yellow light, but when 
our brains see green and red extremely close to each other (like on a tv) 
it tells you that that is yellow.

captions.text: Here we will explore true facts about the mantis shrimp.
The Mantis Shrimp is a living fossil of the prehistoric clown, that all modern clowns evolved from.
It is both beautiful and...wait is that a fish tail?
what are you doing to that fish?
The eyes of the mantis shrimp are among the most advanced eyes in the animal kingdom.
These are very complicated eyes.
Lots of tiny little eye parts moving in different directions.
It's impossible to get a read on what these little bastards are thinking.
is it mad? No.
Each of our human eyes creates a single picture and the two together means that we have binocular vision.
Each one of the mantis shrimp's eyes creates three separate images.
A trinocular eyeball. And it has two of them, which means that it's sexnocular.
Dirty Science.
what was that?! you can clean your eyeballs? thats crazy.
Human eyes can detect three color wavelengths.
The mantis shrimp can detect 5,400 of them.
Just kidding they can detect 12, nine more than we can.
That's less impressive now isn't it, just nine, whatever.
Imagine a color that can't even imagine. Now do that 9 more times. That is how a mantis shrimp do.
Oddly the mantis shrimp is pretty bad at discerning the colors that humans can see.
Which is probably why it dresses like an idiot. And this explains the modern clown as well.
And just like the modern clown the mantis shrimp has a psychopathic killing instinct.
Mantis shrimps are generally divided into two categories.
The first, the spears, have spiny barbed front scooping claws designed to snag and stab prey.
The Spears play a version of hide and go seek.
Which pretty much sucks for anyone that isn't hiding.
Kind of a crappy game, really, not for kids.
alternatively the Smasher mantis shrimp have little, Edward bowling ball hands, that they use to punch the crap out of basically, everything.
They have the fastest punch in the world, with the same acceleration as a 22 caliber bullet.
To a mantis shrimp kung fu looks like thai chi.
The mantis shrimp can deliver a blow with 15,000 Newtons of force, which tells you what a sissy punch Newton must have had.
That punch is so powerful that the universe can't even handle it
water moves out of the way so fast that little vacuums are formed, called cavitation bubbles.
These bubbles collapse immediately, and the force of that collapse creates a second shockwave
and even generates light and heat.
That's some mortal kombat finishing move shit right there.
Basically it sucks to be the mantis shrimp's roommate. Theres just way too much of the punching.
Did that guy just hand him his own arm? thats crazy.
have you ever heard the story of the hermit crab and the mantis shrimp?
One day
That's it, that's the whole story.
Even the octopus, who is quite a badass, can't deal with these little psycho bastards.
If your afraid of clowns, what the hell man leave the crab alone.
If your afraid of clowns, stay afraid.
Stay very afraid.
God Damnit
